list.title: ACCEPTED
list.description: The request has been received but not yet acted upon. It is non-committal, meaning that there is no way in HTTP to later send an asynchronous response indicating the outcome of processing the request. It is intended for cases where another process or server handles the request, or for batch processing.

list.title: BAD_GATEWAY
list.description: This error response means that the server, while working as a gateway to get a response needed to handle the request, got an invalid response.

list.title: BAD_REQUEST
list.description: This response means that server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax.

list.title: BadGatewayError
list.description: BadGatewayError constructor

list.title: BadRequestError
list.description: BadRequestError constructor

list.title: CONFLICT
list.description: This response is sent when a request conflicts with the current state of the server.

list.title: CONTENT_TOO_LARGE
list.description: Request entity is larger than limits defined by server; the server might close the connection or return an Retry-After header field.

list.title: CONTINUE
list.description: This interim response indicates that everything so far is OK and that the client should continue with the request or ignore it if it is already finished.

list.title: CREATED
list.description: The request has succeeded and a new resource has been created as a result of it. This is typically the response sent after a PUT request.

list.title: ConflictError
list.description: ConflictError constructor

list.title: ContentTooLargeError
list.description: ContentTooLargeError constructor

list.title: EARLY_HINTS
list.description: This code indicates to the client that the server is likely to send a final response with the header fields included in the informational response.

list.title: EXPECTATION_FAILED
list.description: This response code means the expectation indicated by the Expect request header field can't be met by the server.

list.title: ExpectationFailedError
list.description: ExpectationFailedError constructor

list.title: FAILED_DEPENDENCY
list.description: The request failed due to failure of a previous request.

list.title: FORBIDDEN
list.description: The client does not have access rights to the content, i.e. they are unauthorized, so server is rejecting to give proper response. Unlike 401, the client's identity is known to the server.

list.title: ForbiddenError
list.description: ForbiddenError constructor

list.title: GATEWAY_TIMEOUT
list.description: This error response is given when the server is acting as a gateway and cannot get a response in time.

list.title: GONE
list.description: This response would be sent when the requested content has been permenantly deleted from server, with no forwarding address. Clients are expected to remove their caches and links to the resource. The HTTP specification intends this status code to be used for "limited-time, promotional services". APIs should not feel compelled to indicate resources that have been deleted with this status code.

list.title: GatewayTimeoutError
list.description: GatewayTimeoutError constructor

list.title: GoneError
list.description: GoneError constructor

list.title: HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED
list.description: The HTTP version used in the request is not supported by the server.

list.title: IM_A_TEAPOT
list.description: Any attempt to brew coffee with a teapot should result in the error code "418 I'm a teapot". The resulting entity body MAY be short and stout.

list.title: INSUFFICIENT_STORAGE
list.description: The server has an internal configuration error: the chosen variant resource is configured to engage in transparent content negotiation itself, and is therefore not a proper end point in the negotiation process.

list.title: INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR
list.description: The server encountered an unexpected condition that prevented it from fulfilling the request.

list.title: ImATeapotError
list.description: ImATeapotError constructor

list.title: InternalServerError
list.description: InternalServerError constructor

list.title: LENGTH_REQUIRED
list.description: The server rejected the request because the Content-Length header field is not defined and the server requires it.

list.title: LOCKED
list.description: The resource that is being accessed is locked.

list.title: LengthRequiredError
list.description: LengthRequiredError constructor

list.title: METHOD_NOT_ALLOWED
list.description: The request method is known by the server but has been disabled and cannot be used. For example, an API may forbid DELETE-ing a resource. The two mandatory methods, GET and HEAD, must never be disabled and should not return this error code.

list.title: MISDIRECTED_REQUEST
list.description: Defined in the specification of HTTP/2 to indicate that a server is not able to produce a response for the combination of scheme and authority that are included in the request URI.

list.title: MOVED_PERMANENTLY
list.description: This response code means that URI of requested resource has been changed. Probably, new URI would be given in the response.

list.title: MOVED_TEMPORARILY
list.description: This response code means that URI of requested resource has been changed temporarily. New changes in the URI might be made in the future. Therefore, this same URI should be used by the client in future requests.

list.title: MULTIPLE_CHOICES
list.description: The request has more than one possible responses. User-agent or user should choose one of them. There is no standardized way to choose one of the responses.

list.title: MULTI_STATUS
list.description: A Multi-Status response conveys information about multiple resources in situations where multiple status codes might be appropriate.

list.title: MethodNotAllowedError
list.description: MethodNotAllowedError constructor

list.title: MethodNotAllowedError#toPojo
list.description: Plain object representation of the error

list.title: NETWORK_AUTHENTICATION_REQUIRED
list.description: The 511 status code indicates that the client needs to authenticate to gain network access.

list.title: NON_AUTHORITATIVE_INFORMATION
list.description: This response code means returned meta-information set is not exact set as available from the origin server, but collected from a local or a third party copy. Except this condition, 200 OK response should be preferred instead of this response.

list.title: NOT_ACCEPTABLE
list.description: This response is sent when the web server, after performing server-driven content negotiation, doesn't find any content following the criteria given by the user agent.

list.title: NOT_FOUND
list.description: The server can not find requested resource. In the browser, this means the URL is not recognized. In an API, this can also mean that the endpoint is valid but the resource itself does not exist. Servers may also send this response instead of 403 to hide the existence of a resource from an unauthorized client. This response code is probably the most famous one due to its frequent occurence on the web.

list.title: NOT_IMPLEMENTED
list.description: The request method is not supported by the server and cannot be handled. The only methods that servers are required to support (and therefore that must not return this code) are GET and HEAD.

list.title: NOT_MODIFIED
list.description: This is used for caching purposes. It is telling to client that response has not been modified. So, client can continue to use same cached version of response.

list.title: NO_CONTENT
list.description: There is no content to send for this request, but the headers may be useful. The user-agent may update its cached headers for this resource with the new ones.

list.title: NotAcceptableError
list.description: NotAcceptableError constructor

list.title: NotFoundError
list.description: NotFoundError constructor

list.title: NotImplementedError
list.description: NotImplementedError constructor

list.title: OK
list.description: The request has succeeded. The meaning of a success varies depending on the HTTP method:

list.title: Options
list.description: Options

list.title: PARTIAL_CONTENT
list.description: This response code is used because of range header sent by the client to separate download into multiple streams.

list.title: PAYMENT_REQUIRED
list.description: This response code is reserved for future use. Initial aim for creating this code was using it for digital payment systems however this is not used currently.

list.title: PERMANENT_REDIRECT
list.description: This means that the resource is now permanently located at another URI, specified by the Location: HTTP Response header. This has the same semantics as the 301 Moved Permanently HTTP response code, with the exception that the user agent must not change the HTTP method used: if a POST was used in the first request, a POST must be used in the second request.

list.title: PRECONDITION_FAILED
list.description: The client has indicated preconditions in its headers which the server does not meet.

list.title: PRECONDITION_REQUIRED
list.description: The origin server requires the request to be conditional. Intended to prevent the 'lost update' problem, where a client GETs a resource's state, modifies it, and PUTs it back to the server, when meanwhile a third party has modified the state on the server, leading to a conflict.

list.title: PROCESSING
list.description: This code indicates that the server has received and is processing the request, but no response is available yet.

list.title: PROXY_AUTHENTICATION_REQUIRED
list.description: This is similar to 401 but authentication is needed to be done by a proxy.

list.title: PaymentRequiredError
list.description: NotFoundError constructor

list.title: PreconditionFailedError
list.description: PreconditionFailedError constructor

list.title: ProxyAuthenticationRequiredError
list.description: ProxyAuthenticationRequiredError constructor

list.title: RANGE_NOT_SATISFIABLE
list.description: The range specified by the Range header field in the request can't be fulfilled; it's possible that the range is outside the size of the target URI's data.

list.title: REQUEST_HEADER_FIELDS_TOO_LARGE
list.description: The server is unwilling to process the request because its header fields are too large. The request MAY be resubmitted after reducing the size of the request header fields.

list.title: REQUEST_TIMEOUT
list.description: This response is sent on an idle connection by some servers, even without any previous request by the client. It means that the server would like to shut down this unused connection. This response is used much more since some browsers, like Chrome, Firefox 27+, or IE9, use HTTP pre-connection mechanisms to speed up surfing. Also note that some servers merely shut down the connection without sending this message.

list.title: RESET_CONTENT
list.description: This response code is sent after accomplishing request to tell user agent reset document view which sent this request.

list.title: RangeNotSatisfiableError
list.description: RangeNotSatisfiableError constructor

list.title: RequestTimeoutError
list.description: RequestTimeoutError constructor

list.title: ResponseError
list.description: ResponseError constructor

list.title: ResponseError#status
list.description: Error status

list.title: ResponseError#toJSON
list.description: Plain object representation of the error

list.title: ResponseError#toPojo
list.description: Plain object representation of the error

list.title: ResponseError#toString
list.description: String representation of the error

list.title: ResponseErrorFactory.create
list.description: Creates a ResponseError instance.

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions
list.description: ResponseErrorOptions constructor

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions#code
list.description: Get the code

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions#details
list.description: Get the details

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions#message
list.description: Get the message

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions#options
list.description: Get the options

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions#requestId
list.description: Get the request id

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions#reset
list.description: Reset the options to the default values

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions#toJSON
list.description: Plain object representation of the options

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions.defaultOptions
list.description: Default options

list.title: ResponseErrorOptions.parseCode
list.description: Normalize the code and use the fallbacks if the code is empty or is not a number

list.title: SEE_OTHER
list.description: Server sent this response to directing client to get requested resource to another URI with an GET request.

list.title: SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE
list.description: The server is not ready to handle the request. Common causes are a server that is down for maintenance or that is overloaded. Note that together with this response, a user-friendly page explaining the problem should be sent. This responses should be used for temporary conditions and the Retry-After: HTTP header should, if possible, contain the estimated time before the recovery of the service. The webmaster must also take care about the caching-related headers that are sent along with this response, as these temporary condition responses should usually not be cached.

list.title: SWITCHING_PROTOCOLS
list.description: This code is sent in response to an Upgrade request header by the client, and indicates the protocol the server is switching too.

list.title: ServiceUnavailableError
list.description: ServiceUnavailableError constructor

list.title: TEMPORARY_REDIRECT
list.description: Server sent this response to directing client to get requested resource to another URI with same method that used prior request. This has the same semantic than the 302 Found HTTP response code, with the exception that the user agent must not change the HTTP method used: if a POST was used in the first request, a POST must be used in the second request.

list.title: TOO_MANY_REQUESTS
list.description: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ("rate limiting").

list.title: TooManyRequestsError
list.description: TooManyRequestsError constructor

list.title: UNAUTHORIZED
list.description: Although the HTTP standard specifies "unauthorized", semantically this response means "unauthenticated". That is, the client must authenticate itself to get the requested response.

list.title: UNAVAILABLE_FOR_LEGAL_REASONS
list.description: The user-agent requested a resource that cannot legally be provided, such as a web page censored by a government.

list.title: UNPROCESSABLE_ENTITY
list.description: The request was well-formed but was unable to be followed due to semantic errors.

list.title: UNSUPPORTED_MEDIA_TYPE
list.description: The media format of the requested data is not supported by the server, so the server is rejecting the request.

list.title: UPGRADE_REQUIRED
list.description: The server refuses to perform the request using the current protocol but might be willing to do so after the client upgrades to a different protocol.

list.title: URI_TOO_LONG
list.description: The URI requested by the client is longer than the server is willing to interpret.

list.title: UnauthorizedError
list.description: UnauthorizedError constructor

list.title: UnavailableForLegalReasonsError
list.description: UnavailableForLegalReasonsError constructor

list.title: UnprocessableEntityError
list.description: UnprocessableEntityError constructor

list.title: UnsupportedMediaTypeError
list.description: UnsupportedMediaTypeError constructor

list.title: UriToLongError
list.description: UriToLongError constructor

list.title: main.js
list.description: Main entry point for the HttpResponseError library.

list.title: module.exports.ACCEPTED
list.description: The request has been received but not yet acted upon. It is non-committal, meaning that there is no way in HTTP to later send an asynchronous response indicating the outcome of processing the request. It is intended for cases where another process or server handles the request, or for batch processing.

list.title: module.exports.BAD_GATEWAY
list.description: This error response means that the server, while working as a gateway to get a response needed to handle the request, got an invalid response.

list.title: module.exports.BAD_REQUEST
list.description: This response means that server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax.

list.title: module.exports.CONFLICT
list.description: This response is sent when a request conflicts with the current state of the server.

list.title: module.exports.CONTENT_TOO_LARGE
list.description:
Request entity is larger than limits defined by server; the server might close the connection or return a Retry-After header field.

Prior to RFC 9110 the response phrase for the status was Payload Too Large. That name is still widely used.

list.title: module.exports.CONTINUE
list.description: This interim response indicates that everything so far is OK and that the client should continue with the request or ignore it if it is already finished.

list.title: module.exports.CREATED
list.description: The request has succeeded and a new resource has been created as a result of it. This is typically the response sent after a PUT request.

list.title: module.exports.EARLY_HINTS
list.description: This code indicates to the client that the server is likely to send a final response with the header fields included in the informational response.

list.title: module.exports.EXPECTATION_FAILED
list.description: This response code means the expectation indicated by the Expect request header field can't be met by the server.

list.title: module.exports.FAILED_DEPENDENCY
list.description: The request failed due to failure of a previous request.

list.title: module.exports.FORBIDDEN
list.description: The client does not have access rights to the content, i.e. they are unauthorized, so server is rejecting to give proper response. Unlike 401, the client's identity is known to the server.

list.title: module.exports.GATEWAY_TIMEOUT
list.description: This error response is given when the server is acting as a gateway and cannot get a response in time.

list.title: module.exports.GONE
list.description: This response would be sent when the requested content has been permanently deleted from server, with no forwarding address. Clients are expected to remove their caches and links to the resource. The HTTP specification intends this status code to be used for "limited-time, promotional services". APIs should not feel compelled to indicate resources that have been deleted with this status code.

list.title: module.exports.HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED
list.description: The HTTP version used in the request is not supported by the server.

list.title: module.exports.IM_A_TEAPOT
list.description: Any attempt to brew coffee with a teapot should result in the error code "418 I'm a teapot". The resulting entity body MAY be short and stout.

list.title: module.exports.INSUFFICIENT_STORAGE
list.description: The 507 (Insufficient Storage) status code means the method could not be performed on the resource because the server is unable to store the representation needed to successfully complete the request. This condition is considered to be temporary. If the request which received this status code was the result of a user action, the request MUST NOT be repeated until it is requested by a separate user action.

list.title: module.exports.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR
list.description: The server encountered an unexpected condition that prevented it from fulfilling the request.

list.title: module.exports.LENGTH_REQUIRED
list.description: The server rejected the request because the Content-Length header field is not defined and the server requires it.

list.title: module.exports.LOCKED
list.description: The resource that is being accessed is locked.

list.title: module.exports.METHOD_NOT_ALLOWED
list.description: The request method is known by the server but has been disabled and cannot be used. For example, an API may forbid DELETE-ing a resource. The two mandatory methods, GET and HEAD, must never be disabled and should not return this error code.

list.title: module.exports.MISDIRECTED_REQUEST
list.description: Defined in the specification of HTTP/2 to indicate that a server is not able to produce a response for the combination of scheme and authority that are included in the request URI.

list.title: module.exports.MOVED_PERMANENTLY
list.description: This response code means that URI of requested resource has been changed. Probably, new URI would be given in the response.

list.title: module.exports.MOVED_TEMPORARILY
list.description: This response code means that URI of requested resource has been changed temporarily. New changes in the URI might be made in the future. Therefore, this same URI should be used by the client in future requests.

list.title: module.exports.MULTIPLE_CHOICES
list.description: The request has more than one possible responses. User-agent or user should choose one of them. There is no standardized way to choose one of the responses.

list.title: module.exports.MULTI_STATUS
list.description: A Multi-Status response conveys information about multiple resources in situations where multiple status codes might be appropriate.

list.title: module.exports.NETWORK_AUTHENTICATION_REQUIRED
list.description: The 511 status code indicates that the client needs to authenticate to gain network access.

list.title: module.exports.NON_AUTHORITATIVE_INFORMATION
list.description: This response code means returned meta-information set is not exact set as available from the origin server, but collected from a local or a third party copy. Except this condition, 200 OK response should be preferred instead of this response.

list.title: module.exports.NOT_ACCEPTABLE
list.description: This response is sent when the web server, after performing server-driven content negotiation, doesn't find any content following the criteria given by the user agent.

list.title: module.exports.NOT_FOUND
list.description: The server can not find requested resource. In the browser, this means the URL is not recognized. In an API, this can also mean that the endpoint is valid but the resource itself does not exist. Servers may also send this response instead of 403 to hide the existence of a resource from an unauthorized client. This response code is probably the most famous one due to its frequent occurrence on the web.

list.title: module.exports.NOT_IMPLEMENTED
list.description: The request method is not supported by the server and cannot be handled. The only methods that servers are required to support (and therefore that must not return this code) are GET and HEAD.

list.title: module.exports.NOT_MODIFIED
list.description: This is used for caching purposes. It is telling to client that response has not been modified. So, client can continue to use same cached version of response.

list.title: module.exports.NO_CONTENT
list.description: There is no content to send for this request, but the headers may be useful. The user-agent may update its cached headers for this resource with the new ones.

list.title: module.exports.OK
list.description: The request has succeeded. The meaning of a success varies depending on the HTTP method:

list.title: module.exports.PARTIAL_CONTENT
list.description: This response code is used because of range header sent by the client to separate download into multiple streams.

list.title: module.exports.PAYMENT_REQUIRED
list.description: This response code is reserved for future use. Initial aim for creating this code was using it for digital payment systems however this is not used currently.

list.title: module.exports.PERMANENT_REDIRECT
list.description: This means that the resource is now permanently located at another URI, specified by the Location HTTP Response header. This has the same semantics as the 301 Moved Permanently HTTP response code, with the exception that the user agent must not change the HTTP method used: if a POST was used in the first request, a POST must be used in the second request.

list.title: module.exports.PRECONDITION_FAILED
list.description: The client has indicated preconditions in its headers which the server does not meet.

list.title: module.exports.PRECONDITION_REQUIRED
list.description: The origin server requires the request to be conditional. Intended to prevent the 'lost update' problem, where a client GETs a resource's state, modifies it, and PUTs it back to the server, when meanwhile a third party has modified the state on the server, leading to a conflict.

list.title: module.exports.PROCESSING
list.description: This code indicates that the server has received and is processing the request, but no response is available yet.

list.title: module.exports.PROXY_AUTHENTICATION_REQUIRED
list.description: This is similar to 401 but authentication is needed to be done by a proxy.

list.title: module.exports.RANGE_NOT_SATISFIABLE
list.description: The range specified by the Range header field in the request can't be fulfilled; it's possible that the range is outside the size of the target URI's data.

list.title: module.exports.REQUEST_HEADER_FIELDS_TOO_LARGE
list.description: The server is unwilling to process the request because its header fields are too large. The request MAY be resubmitted after reducing the size of the request header fields.

list.title: module.exports.REQUEST_TIMEOUT
list.description: This response is sent on an idle connection by some servers, even without any previous request by the client. It means that the server would like to shut down this unused connection. This response is used much more since some browsers, like Chrome, Firefox 27+, or IE9, use HTTP pre-connection mechanisms to speed up surfing. Also note that some servers merely shut down the connection without sending this message.

list.title: module.exports.RESET_CONTENT
list.description: This response code is sent after accomplishing request to tell user agent reset document view which sent this request.

list.title: module.exports.SEE_OTHER
list.description: Server sent this response to directing client to get requested resource to another URI with an GET request.

list.title: module.exports.SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE
list.description: The server is not ready to handle the request. Common causes are a server that is down for maintenance or that is overloaded. Note that together with this response, a user-friendly page explaining the problem should be sent. This responses should be used for temporary conditions and the Retry-After: HTTP header should, if possible, contain the estimated time before the recovery of the service. The webmaster must also take care about the caching-related headers that are sent along with this response, as these temporary condition responses should usually not be cached.

list.title: module.exports.SWITCHING_PROTOCOLS
list.description: This code is sent in response to an Upgrade request header by the client, and indicates the protocol the server is switching too.

list.title: module.exports.TEMPORARY_REDIRECT
list.description: Server sent this response to directing client to get requested resource to another URI with same method that used prior request. This has the same semantic that the 302 Found HTTP response code, with the exception that the user agent must not change the HTTP method used: if a POST was used in the first request, a POST must be used in the second request.

list.title: module.exports.TOO_MANY_REQUESTS
list.description: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ("rate limiting").

list.title: module.exports.UNAUTHORIZED
list.description: Although the HTTP standard specifies "unauthorized", semantically this response means "unauthenticated". That is, the client must authenticate itself to get the requested response.

list.title: module.exports.UNAVAILABLE_FOR_LEGAL_REASONS
list.description: The user-agent requested a resource that cannot legally be provided, such as a web page censored by a government.

list.title: module.exports.UNPROCESSABLE_ENTITY
list.description: The request was well-formed but was unable to be followed due to semantic errors.

list.title: module.exports.UNSUPPORTED_MEDIA_TYPE
list.description: The media format of the requested data is not supported by the server, so the server is rejecting the request.

list.title: module.exports.UPGRADE_REQUIRED
list.description: The server refuses to perform the request using the current protocol but might be willing to do so after the client upgrades to a different protocol.

list.title: module.exports.URI_TOO_LONG
list.description: The URI requested by the client is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
